metadata.case_name: Appellant Private Limited Company v. Income-tax Officer

facts.text: Appellant is a private limited company formed under Companies Act 1956 to take over assets, liabilities and contracts of predecessor company.

Predecessor company obtained lease of forest land in North Andaman for timber exploitation and chartered vessels including Eastern Venture owned by Newland Steamship Co. Ltd. Hongkong via charter-party dated 25.8.1954 in London for 6 months with option, renewed/extended.
Charter-party clause 6: Hire at 16s per ton on 5250 tons deadweight per 30 days, payable without discount every 30 days in advance in cash in Calcutta.
Clause 26: Hire per clause 6 payable by telegraphic transfer to London; addendum: cash in London or Hongkong.
Clause 14: Charterers to advance to Master necessary funds for ordinary disbursements at any port, charging 6% p.a. interest, deducted from hire.
Clause 25: Owners pay 3% commission to Clegg, Cruickshank & Co. Ltd., Calcutta, and others in London.
Vessel plied mainly between Calcutta and North Andaman; required income-tax clearance for port clearance.
Clegg, Cruickshank & Co. Ltd. and appellant undertook to pay income-tax on owners' freight earnings; ITO issued clearances till Feb 1956.
ITO letter 21.2.1956 inquired if hire paid per clause 6 and amount paid/payable to non-resident owners.

Appellant reply 6.3.1956: Hire paid per clause 26 in London; annexed statement: disbursements Rs.52,109-11-0 (Sep54-Mar55), Rs.69,768-13-6 (Apr55-Feb56) comprising advances to master, repairs, commission to local agents; net remitted to London.
ITO letter 17.3.1956: Disbursements constructively received in India by non-resident owner; liable to deduct tax u/s 18(3B); challans enclosed, pay by end March 1956.
Vessel changed hands: to Pan Norse Steamship Co. S.A. Panama, then Wallem & Co. Ltd.; offered Rs.5000 compromise, rejected.
Appellant paid tax via three challans on 18.5.1956.
Appellant filed writ petition u/Art 226 on 18.5.1956 for certiorari quashing proceedings; rule issued, discharged by Sinha J.
Appellant preferred appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner on 7.6.1956, pending; not disclosed to court till later.
Of disbursements: Rs.32,092-5-9 to Clegg etc., Rs.9,028 repairs/bunker to Indian residents.

legal_issues.text: Whether disbursements under clause 14 constitute loans or part-payments of hire constructively received in India by non-resident owners, chargeable u/s 18(3B) IT Act requiring deduction of tax.
Whether writ of certiorari lies against ITO's order despite alternative remedy of appeal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Disbursements paid under clause 14 are loans to owners (advance to master with 6% interest), not chargeable as borrowings not income.
Even if part-payments of hire, not received by owners in India (paid in Calcutta but to master/agents, net remitted London).
Disbursements are gross receipts, not income till expenses deducted; or earmarked for expenditure hence not income.

respondent_arguments.text: Disbursements constitute constructive receipt in India by non-resident owners; liable u/s 18(3B) and 18(7).
Writ does not lie as ITO had jurisdiction; error if any not apparent on face; alternative remedy exists.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant treated disbursements as pre-payments deducted from hire, not loans (no interest charged, full hire less disbursements remitted each month).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Statement to ITO shows hire less disbursements remitted; exchange approvals on same basis.

court_reasoning.text: Under charter-party authorities, advances u/clause 14 with deduction from hire and interest provision are pre-payments, not loans.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provision for deduction indicates part-payment; interest as rebate for prepayment.

court_reasoning.text: Even if initially loans, repaid by deduction from hire in Calcutta, constituting constructive receipt by owners in India.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Charterer cannot repay itself with own money; hire portion applied as owners' money.

court_reasoning.text: 'Chargeable under the Act' u/s 18(3B) includes gross receipts liable to computation under heads in s.6, not just net taxable income.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.18(3C) contemplates gross sums; payer not concerned with ultimate assessment.

court_reasoning.text: Earmarking for expenditure irrelevant; nature determined on receipt, not subsequent use.
ITO's letter is speaking order with reasons (constructive receipt); error if any correctable by certiorari.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Modern scope includes errors of law on face of record.

court_reasoning.text: Writ denied also due to lack of candor: appellant pursued parallel appeal without disclosure.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discretionary jurisdiction not invoked when alternative remedy pursued.

holdings.text: Disbursements are pre-payments of hire or constructively received in India; chargeable u/s 18(3B); appellant liable to deduct tax.
Certiorari not issued due to merits and procedural conduct.

precedents_cited.case_name: Allison v. Bristol Marine Insurance Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Advances to master under charter-party are pre-payments if deductible from freight, not loans.

precedents_cited.case_name: Keshav Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Money applied in India under instruction to pay creditors is receipt in India.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Corporation of London as Conservators of Epping Forest
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Annual payment' includes gross receipts, not just pure income; earmarking irrelevant.
Absence of deduction provision indicates loan; presence suggests pre-payment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Aggarwal Chamber of Commerce Ltd. v. Ganpat Rai Hiralal
precedents_cited.relevance: Payer deducts on gross receipts; not concerned with net taxability.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of U.P. v. Mohammad Nooh
precedents_cited.relevance: Writ possible despite alternative remedy in certain cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rashid and Sons v. Income-tax Investigation Commission
precedents_cited.relevance: Decline writ if parallel remedy pursued.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rex v. Northumberland Compensation Appeal Tribunal, Ex parte Shaw
precedents_cited.relevance: Certiorari corrects errors of law on face of record.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Deduction at source on payments to non-residents of sums chargeable under Act; liability if failure.

outcome.summary: Appeal against discharge of rule in writ petition dismissed; upheld ITO's demand for tax deduction u/s 18(3B) on disbursements as constructive receipt by non-resident owners.

key_quotes.text: "the advances made under clause 14 were not loans, but were pre-payments of a part of the hire"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on nature of disbursements.

key_quotes.text: "if the requisite portion of the hire had to become the owners money in Calcutta before it could be applied to the repayment of the charterers debt, it was... constructively received by the owners in Calcutta"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains constructive receipt even if loans.

key_quotes.text: "chargeable under the provisions of this Act means... liable in its nature to be brought into computation in an assessment, that is to say, as belonging to one or other of the heads of income"
key_quotes.speaker: court
